name: C# Basics
description: Learn the fundamentals of C# programming, including syntax, variables, control structures, and object-oriented programming through theory and practical tasks.

lessons.title: Introduction to C#
lessons.content:
C# is a modern, object-oriented programming language developed by Microsoft in 2000.

Key features:
- Part of the .NET ecosystem
- Strongly typed language (type safety)
- Supports Object-Oriented Programming (OOP)
- Cross-platform with .NET Core
- Used for web apps, desktop apps, games (Unity), and mobile apps

C# combines the power of C++ with the simplicity of Visual Basic, making it perfect for beginners and professionals alike.

lessons.title: Variables and Data Types
lessons.content:
Variables store data in your programs. C# is strongly typed, meaning every variable must have a specific type.

Primitive Data Types:
- int: whole numbers (-2,147,483,648 to 2,147,483,647)
- double: decimal numbers (15-16 digits precision)
- float: decimal numbers (6-7 digits precision)
- string: text in double quotes
- char: single character in single quotes
- bool: true or false

Variables must be declared before use. Use meaningful names in camelCase.

lessons.title: Operators and Expressions
lessons.content:
Operators perform operations on variables and values.

Arithmetic Operators:
+ (addition), - (subtraction), * (multiplication), / (division), % (modulus)

Comparison Operators:
== (equal), != (not equal), > (greater), < (less), >= (greater or equal), <= (less or equal)

Logical Operators:
&& (AND), || (OR), ! (NOT)

Assignment Operators:
= (assign), += (add and assign), -=, *=, /=, ++, --

Which operator checks if two values are NOT equal?

lessons.title: Control Structures: If-Else
lessons.content:
Control structures allow your program to make decisions and execute different code based on conditions.

The if statement executes code only if a condition is true.
The else statement provides an alternative when the condition is false.
The else if allows checking multiple conditions sequentially.

quizQuestions.questionText: Which keyword is used for a conditional statement in C#?
quizQuestions.options:
A) switch
B) if
C) for
D) while

quizQuestions.questionText: What happens if an if condition is false and there's no else statement?
quizQuestions.options:
A) Program crashes
B) Nothing happens, code continues
C) Error is thrown
D) Program exits

quizQuestions.questionText: Can you have multiple else if statements?
quizQuestions.options:
A) No, only one
B) Yes, unlimited
C) Yes, maximum 5
D) No, use switch instead

lessons.title: Loops: For and While
lessons.content:
Loops allow you to repeat code multiple times without writing it repeatedly.

for loop: Use when you know how many times to repeat.
while loop: Use when you repeat based on a condition.
do-while loop: Like while, but executes at least once.

Loop control:
- break: exits the loop immediately
- continue: skips current iteration

quizQuestions.questionText: What does the 'break' keyword do in a loop?
quizQuestions.options:
A) Pauses the loop
B) Exits the loop
C) Skips one iteration
D) Restarts the loop

quizQuestions.questionText: Which loop always executes at least once?
quizQuestions.options:
A) for
B) while
C) do-while
D) foreach

quizQuestions.questionText: What does 'continue' do in a loop?
quizQuestions.options:
A) Exits the loop
B) Restarts from beginning
C) Skips to next iteration
D) Pauses execution

lessons.title: Arrays
lessons.content:
Arrays store multiple values of the same type in a single variable.

Key points:
- Fixed size (cannot change after creation)
- Zero-indexed (first element is at index 0)
- Access elements using square brackets []
- Use .Length property to get size

Arrays are useful when you need to store collections of related data.

C) No, arrays are fixed size

lessons.title: Methods (Functions)
lessons.content:
Methods are reusable blocks of code that perform specific tasks. They help organize code and avoid repetition.

Method components:
- Return type: what the method returns (void if nothing)
- Name: descriptive name in PascalCase
- Parameters: input values (optional)
- Body: code to execute

Benefits:
- Code reusability
- Better organization
- Easier testing and debugging

quizQuestions.questionText: What keyword is used for a method that doesn't return a value?
quizQuestions.options:

B) empty

quizQuestions.options:

B) Returns a value and exits the method

D) Declares a variable

quizQuestions.questionText: Can a method have multiple parameters?
quizQuestions.options:
A) No, only one
B) Yes, unlimited
C) Yes, maximum 5
D) No parameters allowed

lessons.title: Introduction to Classes and Objects
lessons.content:
Object-Oriented Programming (OOP) is a programming paradigm based on objects.

Class: A blueprint for creating objects (like a template).
Object: An instance of a class (actual thing created from template).

Class contains:
- Fields: variables that store data
- Properties: controlled access to fields
- Methods: functions that define behavior

OOP Principles:
- Encapsulation: bundling data and methods
- Abstraction: hiding complexity
- Inheritance: reusing code from parent classes
- Polymorphism: objects taking many forms

quizQuestions.options:

quizQuestions.options:

B) To initialize objects
C) To create methods
D) To define classes

lessons.title: Course Summary and Next Steps
lessons.content:
Congratulations! You've completed C# Basics! 🎉

What you've learned:
✓ C# syntax and structure
✓ Variables and data types
✓ Operators and expressions
✓ Control structures (if-else, loops)
✓ Arrays for storing collections
✓ Methods for code reusability
✓ Object-oriented programming basics

Next steps:
1. Practice with coding challenges
2. Build small projects (calculator, to-do list)
3. Learn advanced OOP concepts
4. Explore .NET framework
5. Study LINQ and collections
6. Learn about file handling and databases

Keep coding and never stop learning! 🚀
